column4: So im attempting to upgrade from 10.10 32 bit, to 10.10 64 bit. If i select use entire partition does it erase my data?
Maybe not?
Hey, is there a way he can do a dist-upgrade to a 64-bit version of buntu?

I heard if you reinstall Ubuntu and keep your primary account information the same, your home folder will not be erased at all, and you can still continue where you left off with a few simple commands.
Can anyone here confirm what I said was right?
So to do this, he would have to make a /home partition and move everything to it, provided he went with a default install?
any more info?
You went with a typical, automated install right?
Well, guess what? If he went with a typical install, gparted would show no home.
It would just be /.
Oh, and some swap, I think.
lol i was on psyhcocats last night
Hah.
Well, follow their instructions. THEN you can reinstall Ubuntu with 64-bit without worrying about overwriting home.
Otherwise, the other way to do it would be to copy home to an external deice, reinstall, then replace the contents in your new home from stufff in your old home.
Think of it like taking your prized possessions before bulldozing a house, then putting everything in the new house.
okay ive decided what im gonna do
just repartition it so my new OS is at the begining of the partition, move all my 'old data' to another partition been wanting to do this for awhile anyways
Parted magic is a nice solution for this.
Look it up, burn it to disk, use it. It comes with gparted, uses LXDE so it;s lightweight and less prone to crashing in the middle of changing things.
just gonna use gpartd thats on the installer cd
